notes.content: Substitute: What can be replaced? These might be materials, people, or rules that can be replaced to change the function.

Combine: What features, uses or components can be combined? Are there features of products that could be synthesized to provide a better, more holistic product? If looking at a project rather than a product, are there different team members that can combine their work?

Adapt: What can be slightly tweaked to improve the product or process? Could a solution to one issue be adapted to help solve a different issue? In what ways does the product/process need to change to adapt itself to changing lifestyles?

Modify (or sometimes, minify/magnify): How can the process be changed in a way that changes the outcomes? What can you magnify to emphasize a particular part of the process, or what can you minify to improve the overall efficiency? Can you modify the shape, color, or size?

Put to another use: What benefits might be gained by using the process/product in a different field? Is there another industry in which the product can succeed? How can this product be used in a way that differs from its initial intent?
Eliminate: Sometimes, the best way to make a product better is to eliminate some of the unnecessary components. What can be removed or simplified? Is there a way to better streamline the product?
Reverse: Would changing the sequence of effects produce a different outcome? What can be rearranged, flipped, or swapped?

1. Segmentation

  1. Divide an object into independent parts.
  2. Make an object sectional (for easy assembly or disassembly).
  3. Increase the degree of an object’s segmentation.

2. Extraction (Extracting, Retrieving, Removing)

  1. Extract the “disturbing” part or property from an object.
  2. Extract only the necessary part or property from an object.

3. Local Quality

  1. Transition from homogeneous to heterogeneous structure of an object or outside environment (action).
  2. Different parts of an object should carry out different functions.
  3. Each part of an object should be placed under conditions that are most favorable for its operation.

4. Asymmetry

  1. Replace symmetrical forms with asymmetrical forms.
  2. If an object is already asymmetrical, increase its degree of asymmetry.

5. Consolidation

  1. Consolidate in space homogeneous objects, or objects destined for contiguous operations.
  2. Consolidate in time homogeneous or contiguous operations.

6. Universality

  1. An object can perform several different functions; therefore, other elements can be removed.

7. Nesting (Matrioshka)

  1. One object is placed inside another. That object is placed inside a third one and so on...
  2. An object passes through a cavity in another object.

8. Counterweight

  1. Compensate for the weight of an object by combining it with another object that provides a lifting force.
  2. Compensate for the weight of an object with aerodynamic or hydrodynamic forces influenced by the outside environment.

9. Prior Counteraction

  1. Preload countertension to an object to compensate excessive and undesirable stress.

10. Prior Action

  1. Perform required changes to an object completely or partially in advance.
  2. Place objects in advance so that they can go into action immediately from the most convenient location.

11. Cushon in Advance

  1. Compensate for the relatively low reliability of an object with emergency measures prepared in advance.

12. Equipotentiality

  1. Change the condition of the work in such a way that it will not require lifting or lowering an object.

13. Do It in Reverse

  1. Instead of the direct action dictated by a problem, implement an opposite action (i.e., cooling instead of heating).
  2. Make the movable part of an object, or outside environment, stationary — and stationary part moveable.
  3. Turn an object upside-down.

14. Spheroidality

  1. Replace linear parts with curved parts, flat surfaces with spherical surfaces, and cube shapes with ball shapes.
  2. Use rollers, balls, spirals.
  3. Replace linear motion with rotational motion; utilize centrifugal force.

15. Dynamicity

  1. Characteristics of an object or outside environment, must be altered to provide optimal performance at each stage of an operation.
  2. If an object is immobile, make it mobile. Make it interchangeable.
  3. Divide an object into elements capable of changing their position relative to each other.

16. Partial or Excessive Action

  1. If it is difficult to obtain 100% of a desired effect, achieve more or less of the desired effect.

17. Transition Into a New Dimension

  1. Transition one-dimensional movement, or placement, of objects into two-dimensional; two-dimensional to three-dimensional, etc.
  2. Utilize multi-level composition of objects.
  3. Incline an object, or place it on its side.
  4. Utilize the opposite side of a given surface.
  5. Project optical lines onto neighboring areas, or onto the reverse side, of an object.

18. Mechanical Vibration

  1. Utilize oscillation.
  2. If oscillation exists, increase its frequency to ultrasonic.
  3. Use the frequency of resonance.
  4. Replace mechanical vibrations with piezovibrations.
  5. Use ultrasonic vibrations in conjunction with an electromagnetic field.

19. Periodic Action

  1. Replace a continuous action with a periodic one (impulse).
  2. If the action is already periodic, change its frequency.
  3. Use pauses between impulses to provide additional action.

20. Continuity of Useful Action

  1. Carry out an action without a break. All parts of the object should constantly operate at full capacity.
  2. Remove idle and intermediate motion.
  3. Replace “back-and-forth” motion with a rotating one.

21. Rushing Through

  1. Perform harmful and hazardous operations at a very high speed.

22. Convert Harm Into Benefit

  1. Utilize harmful factors — especially environmental — to obtain a positive effect.
  2. Remove one harmful factor by combining it with another harmful factor.
  3. Increase the degree of harmful action to such an extent that it ceases to be harmful.

23. Feedback

  1. Introduce feedback.
  2. If feedback already exists, change it.

24. Mediator

  1. Use an intermediary object to transfer or carry out an action.
  2. Temporarily connect the original object to one that is easily removed.

25. Self-service

  1. An object must service itself and carry out supplementary and repair operations.
  2. Make use of waste material and energy.

26. Copying

  1. A simplified and inexpensive copy should be used in place of a fragile original or an object that is inconvenient to operate.
  2. If a visible optical copy is used, replace it with an infrared or ultraviolet copies.
  3. Replace an object (or system of objects) with their optical image. The image can then be reduced or enlarged.

27. Dispose

  1. Replace an expensive object with a cheap one, compromising other properties (i.e., longevity).

28. Replacement of Mechanical System

  1. Replace a mechanical system with an optical, acoustical, thermal or olfactory system.
  2. Use an electric, magnetic or electromagnetic field to interact with an object.
  3. Replace fields that are:
    1. Stationary with mobile
    2. Fixed with changing in time
    3. Random with structured
  4. Use fields in conjunction with ferromagnetic

29. Pneumatic or Hydraulic Constructions

  1. Replace solid parts of an object with a gas or liquid. These parts can now use air or water for inflation, or use pneumatic or hydrostatic cushions.

30. Flexible Membranes or Thin Films

  1. Replace customary constructions with flexible membranes or thin film.
  2. Isolate an object from its outside environment with flexible membranes or thin films.

31. Porous Material

  1. Make an object porous, or use supplementary porous elements (inserts, covers, etc.).
  2. If an object is already porous, fill pores in advance with some substance.

32. Changing the Color

  1. Change the color of an object or its environment.
  2. Change the degree of translucency of an object or its environment.
  3. Use color additives to observe an object, or process which is difficult to see.
  4. If such additives are already used, employ luminescent traces or trace atoms.

33. Homogeneity

  1. Objects interacting with the main object should be made out of the same material (or material with similar properties) as the main object.

34. Rejecting and Regenerating Parts

  1. After completing its function, or becoming useless, an element of an object is rejected (discarded, dissolved, evaporated, etc.) or modified during its work process.
  2. Used-up parts of an object should be restored during its work.

35. Transformation of Properties

  1. Change the physical state of the system.
  2. Change the concentration or density.
  3. Change the degree of flexibility.
  4. Change the temperature or volume.

36. Phase Transition

  1. Using the phenomena of phase change (i.e., a change in volume, the liberation or absorption of heat, etc.).

37. Thermal Expansion

  1. Use expansion or contraction of material by changing its temperature.
  2. Use various materials with different coefficients of thermal expansion.

38. Accelerated Oxidation

  1. Make transition from one level of oxidation to the next higher level:
    1. Ambient air to oxygenated
    2. Oxygenated to oxygen
    3. Oxygen to ionized oxygen
    4. Ionized oxygen to ozoned oxygen
    5. Ozoned oxygen to ozone
    6. Ozone to singlet oxygen

39. Inert Environment

  1. Replace a normal environment with an inert one.
  2. Introduce a neutral substance or additives into an object.
  3. Carry out the process in a vacuum.

40. Composite Materials

  1. Replace homogeneous materials with composite ones.

[blank white card]

• If you want to compute in the future, you have to compute with the computing power of the future
    • We spent roughly two to three times a person’s salary each year just on technology for that person
    • We bought our way into the future because Moore’s Law says that if you’re interested in something 15 years from now, you can have that computing power now if you’re willing to pay through the nose
tags: The Future Doesn't Have to Be Incremental

notes.content:
• The iPad has a much more brain dead interface than the Mac
  • But if you think of the iPad as a gesture device, the gesture is inherently something that gives you not just naturalness, but efficiency.
    • What you really want… is to learn a bunch of gestures to make you fluent and efficient on the thing
    • [But] the iPad doesn’t have any particular way of teaching you those gestures.
    • So basically everything has evolved down to the few system gestures that are generic to the iPad.
  • This kind of dumb-downism has been incredibly successful for… making money.
  • It has not been good for personal computing.
tags: The Future Doesn't Have to Be Incremental

notes.content:
• The idea of the Wayne Gretzky Game is to put the puck way out there, like 30 years out.
  • So far out that whatever you think about out there need have no visible way of getting there.
  • It’s just something that would be cool to have and/or important to have.
  • You [then] want to bring it closer in and start thinking about what would this thing be 10 to 15 years out.
  • And you start thinking, hmm, I wonder if there’s something we could do there.
    • But a device like this has hardware and software of the future.
    • And we have to do that now, because it’s going to take decades to do fundamental hardware and software for a new kind of thing.
    • And you can get that by paying. You just pay whatever Moore’s Law is going to save you later on.
tags: The Future Doesn't Have to Be Incremental

notes.content:
• A book called “The Human Use of Human Beings”
  • Out of MIT in 1952, by Norbert Wiener
  • The idea of cybernetics as “the study of messages as a means of controlling machinery and society”
  • That is: “let us not look at the person, but let us look at the messages going around”
tags: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• A book called “The Human Use of Human Beings”
  • Out of MIT in 1952, by Norbert Wiener
  • Another idea: we have modified our environment so radically, that we must now modify ourselves in order to exist in this new environment.
  • Then: how can we take a person and simplify it down to a machine, or a system that we can understand well?
    • And then once we are starting to think of people that way, well we can improve machines.
    • We can add things to them and the machines get more capabilities. Maybe that is how we move forward as people.
tags: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• The connecting thread in “Whole Earth Catalog”… is this idea of access to tools
  • Our relationship with our tools is going to be how we move forward
  • This catalog starts with “We are as gods and we might as well get good at it. So far, remotely done power and glory – as government, big business, formal education, church – has succeeded to the point where the gross defects obscure actual gains. In response, personal power is developing.”
tags: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• So I had this idea for intentional communication, the idea of conversation flows:
  • Instead of just having a blank box you write into…
    • You first choose some intent. “My intent is to learn”, let us say.
    • And I will get prompted to, say, “what is your background?”
    • And the question is, “Why do I have to explicitly cast between Int and Float when doing math?”
    • And then I can submit the post.
  • [And then] instead of just having a “reply” button, maybe you can say, “OK, I can either ask for clarification, or I can give an answer”.
    • And so if I say I am going to give an answer, again we might have this structured way of replying.
    • Restate the question, answer it, and then, hey we value citations.
    • And they can post it.
  • So we saw someone wants to learn, you can clarify or answer. If they choose to answer, they can ask a clarifying question, or thank you.
  • The point here is just that “Yell angrily” is not one of the states in the discussion flow. It is unreachable.
tags: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• “Beyond Freedom and Dignity” by B. F. Skinner says: “If planned culture necessarily meant uniformity or regimentation, it might indeed work against further evolution… but if we are looking for variety, we should not fall back upon accident. Many accidental cultures have been marked by uniformity and regimentation.”
  • I think this is one of the clearest books that is recognizing that:
    • there are these people who understand choice architectures, and that
    • freedom does not help you escape from choice architectures.
    • Design of other choice architectures is a way to deal with that.
tags: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• There are two kinds of tools: user-friendly tools, and physics-friendly tools
  • User-friendly tools:
    • Wrap a particular domain around the habits of your mind, via a user-experience metaphor
    • Feel like alert servants, and never let you forget that you exist
    • If you grow good enough at wielding them, they allow you to forget that they exist
  • Physics-friendly tools:
    • Wrap your mind around a particular domain, via an engineer-experience metaphor
    • Feel like real tools, and never let you forget that they exist
    • If you grow good enough at wielding them, they allow you to forget that you exist

• Doing more complex things like building robots takes a higher minimum level of tooling complexity
    • We do not live in a very user-friendly universe, but we do live in a fairly physics-friendly one
    • So you need something like a minimum-viable toolchain to do a given thing
  • Simpler, more user-friendly tooling is
    • the result of improved domain understanding,
    • not increased concern for human comfort and convenience
  • Fundamentally reducing the complexity of tooling required to do a thing requires understanding the thing itself better
    • Premature user-friendliness is the root of all toolchain jankiness, perhaps
    • It moves complexity around without fundamentally reducing it

• A famous 2009 Google paper, The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Data: simple algorithms and more data beat complex algorithms and less data

  • One can also think about AI in terms of time rather than intelligence

    • Modern AI is better understood as “Artificial Time” that can be prosthetically attached to human minds
    • Highly capable computing systems are best understood as existing in superhistory rather than embodying superintelligence

• Augmenting humans with machine learning in the right way raises their effective experiential age.
  • Here is where the training/inference cost asymmetry kicks in:
    • You need vast pools of powerful computers to train the best, biggest models, but
    • you mostly only need much cheaper personal-scale computers to do inference with those models.
  • So the hundreds (or thousands) of years worth of experience:
    • are logged in expensive infrastructure living in superhistorical time, but
    • are usable at human scale in historical time

• Lived human experience is not worth as much as you might think
  • Every scientific or technological revolution tears down yet another anthropocentric conceit
    • This one (ML) is tearing down the conceit that our lives are significant in informational terms
    • The humbling thing about the rise of machine learning is
      • not that it shows us how stupid we are in “intelligence” terms, but
      • how empty our lives are, in terms of their information content
  • Ideas like “building a second brain” leverage this basic new potentiality in the human condition:
    • our newfound ability to age faster than we can live, by
    • using machines to do much of the superhistorical living for us

• In information theory, the kind of disorder called entropy is the lack of structure or compressibility in data.
    • Consider a rectangular field of pixels which can be either black or white.
      • A field of pure black or pure white has maximum order in the sense of Shannon entropy
      • you hardly need any bits to explain how to recreate the image.
      • This is not a mess.
    • consider a rectangle of pixels specified by a random process, with black and white equally likely.
      • There is no way to compress this data: each pixel must be specified separately.
      • It has maximum entropy
      • But it is not a mess.
    • consider a rectangle of black and white pixels formed from a series of corporate logos overlapping a background text
      • [it] takes fewer bits to specify than the randomly pixelated rectangle.
      • There are repeated letter forms, geometric forms… There is much more order and compressibility here.
      • And it’s a mess.
  • Why are tableaux that are apparently more orderly (in the sense of compressibility in the data required to specify them) also more messy?
    • For mess to appear, there must be (in the component parts of the mess) an implication of the highly-regular order associated with human intention
    • Mess is only perceptible because it produces in our minds an imaginary order that is missing.
tags: Tendrils of Mess in our Brains

notes.content:
• A great deal of our reality is made from imaginary orders we carry around in our heads.
    • We use these imaginary orders to rebuild, navigate, and judge our world.
    • A mess is a visceral clue to the existence of these invisible orders.
tags: Tendrils of Mess in our Brains

notes.content: • Archibald Hill: “All writing represents speech”; John DeFrancis: “Writing is visible speech.”

• Vowel signs come from the Greeks repurposing Phoenician letters (which were abjadic)
    • They extracted those that didn’t match to sounds in their language, and were thus ‘extra’
    • Example: aleph in Hebrew is the glottal-stop represented by the Phoenician ~k char that was rotated to become the Greek alpha

• “Writing develops for agrarian-administrative purposes” is a now-debunked myth:
    • Mesopotamia/Mycenaean: here, earliest writing does describe borrowing, grain hauls, palace bureaucracy – but…
    • Cypriot/Cretan syllabaries: heroes’ historical exploits
    • Shang oracle bones: religious diviniation
    • Egypt, Mesoamerica: names and titles of royalty
  • Example of the teleological fallacy:
    • assuming a phenomenon originally came into being in order to serve [whatever is its current purpose]
    • e.g. “whale was always a sea creature” – but paleontology disproves
  • Counter-proposal: what’s one aspect of language that
    • cannot be easily conveyed by [mathematical, symbolic, magical, pictorial, etc] notation, but instead
    • needs to be recorded phonetically, as the series of their constituent sounds?
    • Answer: proper nouns - i.e. specific locations, specific people
      • This seems borne out by many cases of writing-system borrowing: - the first people from the borrowing culture to use a preexisting writing system - tend to do so to label items/assert ownership

• Acrophony: the naming of an alphabetic letter in such a way that its name begins with the letter itself.
  • Rune names and rune-values were so tightly coupled that runes were interchangeably used as logograms, e.g. 
    • the rune representing the sound “o” was named othila;
    • “othila” also literally meant “hereditary treasure”;
    • writers would often write “hereditary treasure” with a single letter “o”

• Chinese characters can be divided into five groups:
    • logograms (e.g. man, woman, horse) are directly derive from oracle-bone pictographs
    • representational signs or ideograms (e.g. numbers, up, down) aren’t strict pictographs; they express an abstract idea through an iconic form
    • relational units are a combination of two preexisting signs (e.g. moon and sun characters, written together, mean brightness – because that’s what they have in common)
    • rebus signs are pictographs that represent the image’s sound, not the image itself (e.g. lai as wheat => used as lai meaning to come/arrive)
    • phonetic-semantic signs combine a symbol of meaning with a symbol of sound (these are >90% Chinese characters)

• McLuhan: “The contents of any medium is always another medium”
    • A book conveys its contents: but also conveys writing, which itself is a medium that conveys the medium of speech
    • Books also convey paper, and all the relationships that go into raw-material procurement, refining, printing, distribution, etc

• Memory is a proxy for learning, which is a proxy for meaningful enablement.
  • What questions can we ask about learning?
    • In what circumstances (and to what extent) does reliable memory transfer to open-ended tasks in the subject?
      • Can you explain the topic to someone else?
      • Can you spot unmentioned connections?
      • Can you solve problems you haven’t seen before?
    • What characteristics of prompts seem to promote this type of transfer learning, and through what mechanisms?
  • What about creativity?
    • In Seeing What Others Don’t, Gary Klein suggests that key patterns of insight generation include noticing connections and contradictions
    • Those both seem dependent on what’s in one’s memory: so can memory systems make us more insightful?
    • If we designed a new “memory system” with the sole aim of downstream impact on creative work, what would it look like? Would it involve retrieval practice at all?

• A virtuous cycle:
    • powerful subject-matter ideas enable new systems, and
    • observations of those systems enable new insights into the subject matter.
  • The cycle might involve something like these steps:
    • Identifying powerful insights about some subject domain (or about cognition in general) which might be fruitfully systematized;
    • Building systems which express those insights in their primitives;
    • Observing serious use of those systems in authentic contexts (and of your theoretical insights, as refracted through them);
    • Distilling generalizable insights from those observations, which then
      • produce new understanding about the subject, and
      • allow new, better systems to be built
    • Disseminating that insight so that others can build on it
  • Most people interested in tools for thought are not reliably performing all these steps, which has left the field without a functioning ratchet.

• Ben Shneiderman’s schematic for research project design: the “two parents, three children” pattern
    • [Basic Theories + Applied Problems] => Research Project => [Refined Theories, Practical Solutions, Guidance to Future Researchers]
    • Aligns with Jan van den Akker’s “unit of progress” in ed research: [Educational design] principles are usually heuristic statements of a format such as: “If you want to design intervention X (for the purpose/function Y in context Z), then you are best advised to give that intervention the characteristics A, B, and C (substantive emphasis), and to do that via procedures K, L, and M (procedural emphasis), because of arguments P, Q, and R [(theoretical emphasis)].”

• Two litmus tests for (e.g. SRS) assessments…
  • False positives: How might you produce the correct answer without really knowing the information you intend to know?
    • Discourage pattern matching (a long question with unusual words or cues)
    • Avoid binary prompts (questions which ask for a yes/no or this/that answer)
  • False negatives: How might you know the information the prompt intends to capture but fail to produce the correct answer?
    • Include enough context that reasonable alternative answers are clearly wrong

• As a medium, books have no direct means of communicating with readers over time
    • The physical text is stuck on the page
    • It’s read linearly and continuously in a few sittings
  • To be transformed by a book, readers must do more than absorb information
    • They must
      • ruminate on the book’s ideas and mental models, then
      • relate those ideas to experiences in their lives over weeks and months
    • Unfortunately, readers must drive that process for themselves

• If behavior is a function of a person in their environment (that is, B=f(P,E)), then it’s very difficult to modify P, but at least possible to modify E.
    • The average human has 11 million sensory receptors in their body: 10 million of them are dedicated to sight.
    • Because of this, visual cues in our environment are the most effective at influencing our behavior.

• Habit Stacking: consistently perform some behavior immediately after another behavior.
    • This leverages the Diderot Effect (the human phenomenon where one purchase leads to another, e.g. buying a new desk prompts you to get a new keyboard, mouse, and monitor), but applies it to habits.
    • The format of habit stacking is: After [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT]
    • e.g. if you currently have the habit of making coffee every morning: “After I make coffee, I will sit down at my desk and write.”

• Temptation Bundling: follow up a “good habit” with a habit that you enjoy
    • This causes your brain to associate the good habit with the reward of the enjoyable habit.
    • Temptation bundling generally has the form of: After [HABIT I NEED], I will [HABIT I WANT]
    • e.g. “After I get on the spin bike, I will start listening to my favorite podcast”, “After I open the book I’m reading, I will drink a cup of coffee”
    • The reward should reinforce the identity that is associated with the habit.

• Leverage the “Desire to Belong”
  • We imitate three groups of people:
    • The close (friends and family),
    • The powerful (people with status and prestige), and
    • The many (people in our society)
  • Surround yourself with people who already have the habits that you’re trying to develop.

• “Make it Unattractive”: to break a bad habit, eliminate the craving for that habit.
  • Either:
    • Expose how the bad habit inadequately addresses the underlying motive that caused its formation, or
    • Replace the bad habit with a good habit that more effectively addresses the underlying motive.

• Quantity Over Quality
    • If you want to master a habit, the key is to start with repetition, not perfection.
    • (example of the photography class w/ two groups, “more photos for higher grade” and “best single photo for higher grade”; best photos all came from former group)

• Motion vs Action
    • Reading a book on programming is motion. Actually programming is action.
    • We’re attracted to motion because it gives us the illusion of progress without the risk of failure.
    • Action is more difficult than motion, but it’s also more rewarding.

• Every habit is an obstacle to getting what you really want.
    • Exercising is an obstacle to getting fit. Writing is an obstacle to thinking clearly.
    • You don’t want the habit itself, you want what the habit delivers.
  • Prepare your environment for performing a particular habit ahead of time
    • This serves as both a reminder and a mechanism for making the habit as convenient as possible.
    • If you want to start going to the gym every morning, pack your bag the night before.
    • If you want to read before bed, place a book on your pillowcase every morning.

• Bad > None
    • Anyone can work out when they’re well-rested and feeling energized: but it takes a special commitment to hit the gym on 2 hours of sleep.
    • Cherish the days where you don’t feel like performing a habit, for they provide an opportunity to strengthen your desired identity like no other.
  • Naïve Metrics
    • When tracking habits, keep the bigger picture in mind
    • Don’t become too obsessed with the metric you’ve chosen to track your progress
    • Remember why you’re performing a habit in the first place

• Never Miss Twice
    • Habit building is not an all-or-nothing endeavor: life is full of surprises; we’ll inevitably miss performing our habits one day
    • The trick is to not let this slip up get you down: tell yourself that you’ll never miss twice, and focus on rebounding as soon as possible

• The most important piece of advice when building new habits is to pick habits that you want to develop, not ones that you’re told you should develop.
  • You’ll be much more likely to achieve and maintain the habit you enjoy than the one you dislike: to find these, answer the following:
    • What feels like fun to me, but like work to others?
    • What makes me lose track of time?
    • Where do I experience greater progress returns than the average person?
    • What comes naturally to me?

• To study consciousness, we first need to recognize it
    • Dehaene’s approach to this is simple and bold: a perception or a thought is conscious if you can report on it
    • The beauty of Dehaene’s approach is that he only extracts a single bit of information (yes or no)
  • Dehaene’s book is only about this definition of consciousness
  • It is not about
    • cognition (in the sense of abstract reasoning)
    • meta-cognition (the ability to reflect about your own thoughts)
    • self-consciousness (being aware of oneself)
  • For Dehaene, (the related concept) attention is the gating mechanism that decides which information is allowed to enter consciousness
    • But this process itself is unconscious:
    • we are not aware of all the options that were considered and discarded, only of the winner

• To make perception unconscious in ordinary people…
  • These setups are useful, but they are not 100% reliable, more like 80% at best:
    • You don’t always perceive images consciously if they are presented
      • with a low contrast, or
      • for a short time
    • Binocular rivalry occurs if your two eyes are presented with different images
      • In this case, most of the time you don’t see a weird overlay of the two images, but
      • instead your conscious perception flips between seeing either one or the other
      • NB binocular rivalry is different in autistic people!
    • Attentional blinking describes the effect that
      • after a conscious perception,
      • you are consciously blind for anything that you see in the next 200-300ms
    • With Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) we can stimulate specific brain regions
      • By stimulating sensory areas, we can induce hallucinations, and
      • we can either make them conscious or unconscious by regulating the strength of TMS
      • By interfering with the right region at the right time, we can also prevent real perceptions from entering consciousness
  • One setup which works always, for everyone, is masking
    • The process:
      • you see some shapes (the “mask”),
      • then very briefly an image, and
      • then the shapes again
    • If the image is shown for 30ms, then people do not consciously see it, while for 60ms they do
    • This works with almost 100% accuracy, and has become the main workhorse for consciousness studies

• What can the brain do with unconscious information? A lot.

  • Your unconscious brain does not just process the letters of a word; it also deciphers the meaning.

    • For example, a masked “four” primes you not just for recognizing “four”, but also for “4”, “FOUR”, a spoken “four”, and even for “three”.
    • In fact, it primes you better for “three” than for “two”: the priming is stronger the closer the numbers are.

  • Unconscious perceptions can induce negative emotions

  • You can unconsciously distinguish faces and abstract categories like “object” and “animal”

  • You can unconsciously estimate averages.

  • Unconscious perceptions can control your attention: an unconscious “stop signal” will activate your executive control center in the brain.

  • You can also unconsciously detect errors

  • You can even learn new things unconsciously.

    • If you get a reward after each unconscious presentation, and
    • you get more reward after image A than after image B, then
    • you learn that A is worth more – even if you never consciously see any images at all!

• Unconscious perceptions are almost completely gone after a second
  • This means that tasks which require working memory can not be performed unconsciously.
  • Unconscious traces are too weak to be used as an input for a second step.
  • The exact point of complexity that can be performed unconsciously seems to be very low.
  • After seeing a number n unconsciously,
    • test persons are well above chance for the tasks of:
      • naming n,
      • naming n+2, or
      • deciding whether n<5
    • But deciding whether (n+2)<5 is already at chance level.

• Consciousness has a coordination effect.
  • Imagine you see some line moving in a diagonal direction over the screen.
    • Your neurons in the low-level visual areas cannot “see” the whole picture: they have only a limited perceptive field.
    • As such, it’s impossible to decide from their local information whether the line moves upwards, or to the right, or diagonally.
    • If the image remains unconscious, then these mismatches are never resolved.
    • However, if the image enters consciousness, then after 120-140 ms all neurons in the lower layers suddenly start to encode “it’s moving diagonally”
  • Dehaene’s description of this proces:
    • The unconscious (or pre-conscious) neural activity encodes a probability distribution over the possible states of the world.
      • If we see the word “bank”, then the meaning “credit institute” and “side of river” are both represented by some neurons, so
      • they both occur in this probability distribution.
    • When the word reaches consciousness, then
      • the brain samples from this distribution,
      • it decides one of the possible options, and
      • all neurons are overwritten with this meaning.

• Consciousness enables us to gauge our confidence.
  • That is, test subjects can say “I am certain” or “this was just a guess”.
  • And we are good at this: but only if the task was based on conscious perception.
  • If it is based on unconscious perception, then
    • we may still be good at the task itself, but our self-assessment is inaccurate.
    • often we underestimate our performance.

• Two different types of long-term memory, procedural and episodic
  • Procedural memory allows us to walk, ride a bike, or play the piano.
    • For this review, pooled together with semantic memory
      • the knowledge that birds can fly, or
      • things that you have learned by heart, like a song or the multiplication table.
    • We can acquire and access procedural memory unconsciously.
    • Acquiring procedural memory often requires a lot of practice and repetition.
      • This type of learning is usually slow and decentral in the brain:
      • Only the regions which are directly relevant to the task are involved in this type of learning.

• Two different types of long-term memory, procedural and episodic
  • Episodic memory refers to specific moments of your life,
    • e.g. remembering what you had for breakfast or what your conversation partner said five minutes ago.
    • This type of memory is one-shot: it’s instantaneously formed and does not require any repetition.
    • Aspects of episodic memory can be transferred into procedural/semantic memory
      • Sometimes after a few repetitions; sometimes just once
      • This particular interaction between the two types of memory is quite complicated, however

• Two different types of long-term memory, procedural and episodic
  • Episodic memory without consciousness is plainly impossible
  • However, consciousness also helps for procedural memory
    • Episodic memory can be transferred into procedural memory during sleep, and this is stronger than the effect of the direct experience alone.
    • Moreover, you only connect unconsciously-perceived events with each other if they are simultaneous (after all, unconscious neural activity fades away very, very quickly)

• One theory: the coherent activity of consciousness is exactly the form of neural patterns that can be stored in episodic memory.
  • That is, a conscious perception creates a(n episodic) memory-item that can be stored and retrieved later
  • A crucial property of memory is pattern completion: that you can retrieve the whole memory pattern from activation of a small part
    • So the word “croissant” may trigger the image of a croissant, the smell of it, the taste, the texture, and so on.
    • But the same works vice versa: the smell of a croissant also triggers the rest.
    • That is, there is no core of the concept “croissant” that needs to be present in order to trigger the whole concept.
  • For procedural memory, this is not a big deal
    • Since this memory is formed slowly,
    • there is enough time to nicely embed it into existing structures.
  • But episodic memory is one-shot learning: it needs to be formed in a second
    • It’s really hard to embed a complex concept so deep into an existing network that you still have pattern completion.
    • Every change in the brain needs to be cautious, because you have a lot of systems that should still be working after the change.
    • If each neuron represented its own interpretation of reality, then it would be pretty hopeless to encode all this into a retrievable pattern in just one second.
    • But it gets a lot easier if the activity of all neurons throughout your whole brain are highly consistent with each other… and that is precisely what consciousness seems to achieve

• For an unconscious perception, the main brain activity is in perceptual regions
    • The signal can travel further into the brain, but
    • only reaches a few regions, and
    • gets weaker and weaker.
  • A conscious perception does not get weaker; it gets stronger as it travels.
    • After 400ms, the conscious avalanche has activated large parts of the brain, which Dehaene calls global ignition.
    • All the brain parts synchronize, and information flows from all parts into each other.
    • “flow of information” is a well-defined quantity, measured by so-called Granger causality.
      • Granger causality is a useful concept with
      • a terrible name, since it is about a complex form of correlation, and not about causality.

• Consciousness has a severe disadvantage: it is really slow.
    • A conscious perception takes about half a second, 500ms.
    • This is ages compared to neural transmission speed of 70-100ms.
    • As such, a lot of our everyday life runs on autopilot.
  • Consciousness is also exclusive.
    • While a conscious perception is processed (which may consist of several components, like an image and a compatible sound), the activity blocks off other perceptions
    • They are either missed completely, or can only be processed after the 500ms are over.
  • So our consciousness:
    • runs at most at 2 perceptions per second, and
    • (other than unconscious operations) can not be parallelized.

• So consciousness has upsides and downsides.
  • It is really slow, it is exclusive, and it simplifies the world into a highly compressed sample.
    • This can be useful in its own right, for example to make a decision.
    • A lot of information is lost in this process, but apparently the resulting pattern is so simple that it can be processed further.
  • Since all parts of the brain participate in a conscious event, it is also universally available in the brain.
  • A conscious thought does not need to be triggered from the outside.
    • It can also be the next step of a mental algorithm, like the next thought in a train of thoughts, and
    • It can come (fully or partially) from episodic memory or mental associations.
      • Due to their simplicity, these memory items can often be expressed in language, and thus
      • they can be transmitted to others.

• There are at least two different ways of phrasing what happens when sensory input like the color “red” leads to some neural activity
    • Classically, we would say that “I” or “the brain” experiences the color red. The hard problem of consciousness assumes that this experience is something that goes beyond neural activity.
    • In the book Consciousness Explained, Daniel Dennett argues that a more appropriate description is the multiple drafts model (also called Cartesian theater)
      • the brain is a collection of many different regions
      • Each region acts like a little agent with its own perception.
      • The experience is then just the collection of these local experiences.
  • Critics like John Searle find that the multiple drafts model can’t explain why experiences are first-person, i.e., where the “I” comes from.
    • I think this is precisely the point that Dehaenes’s book helps us to understand.
    • My claim is: Given what we know about consciousness, if we assume the multiple drafts model, then we should naturally expect the subjective perception of a first-person observer.
  • Remember that our episodic memory might be exclusively formed from conscious moments, and also implicit learning gets a strong boost from consciousness.
    • So when “we” (our brain) learn a “mind schema”, then this is based on the conscious moments, not on the activities in between.
    • On this basis, it makes sense to merge all our neural activity into a single unit, which we call “I” or “my mind”.
    • We similarly form the unitary concept of “my body” – but even stronger, since we never “observe” different parts of our mind to be incoherent or even independent.
